bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Wade Hampton Frost, September 1, 1930

div1.p: [Carter] suggests that Frost be the sole editor of the History of Yellow Fever as he has ensured that the book will be published according to Henry Rose Carter's wishes. She also discusses the acknowledgment of Brown's contributions.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Wade Hampton Frost, September 1, 1930
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 1, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
4710 Keswick Road,
Roland Park,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
As an addendum to my letter of last Friday, written very hurriedly
in order to catch the last collection of mail that night:

While I am, as I wrote you, most deeply touched at your heading
the second part of your Preface: “Note by the Editors,” I feel now, as I
felt then, that the final “s,” (for the thought of which I am so grateful!)
) should be deleted. Indeed, I had started my last letter to you with a
statement to that effect, when Grace Brown came in and asked me to wait
and think it over. Being already dissatisfied with the inadequate begin-
ing of my letter (I was, as I said, writing against time and on the type-
writer) I simply jerked out the sheet and started over again, merely ex-
pressing my profound gratitude and appreciation for your generous thought, and
postponing this part of the letter until later.

As I have told you, the fact that the book will be published “as
Father wished it to be,” is due to yourself alone. Also, in order that the
medical profession as a whole may know that this posthumous book will be
so published, it does seem to me that you should sign your name to the
editorial Note. This, if you still do not think it proper to do as I,
suggested and allow your name to appear with Father's on the title page.

Have not yet heard from Mr. Martel, as to the amended form of
acknowledgement to Grace Brown [unclear]. Grace herself, however, to whom I showed
your Preface on her birthday, suggests that you amend it to read:

“The bibliography has been prepared with the assistance of Miss
Grace Brown, of the Catalogue Division of the Library of Congress” etc. This,
if we get nothing better from Martel. Putting in the words “of the Catalogue
Division” helps to vouch for her special equipment for such work. and
also places her, as there are several Miss Browns in the Library. Also it
is “a feather in the cap” of the Division. You, however, know what is pro-
per under the circumstances far better than I.

I am sending you, under separate cover, a few of the library cards
that you wanted looked up. There is explanatory matter on them, which seems
better than putting it in here.

Both of the periodical refs. to Audouard seem unsatisfactory, al-
though I shall make further search to-morrow, when the Army Medical Library
is again open.

The enclosed transcription from Guyon, (Christian name not given,
in Gaz. med. de Paris) makes one very sceptical about Abreu as a ref. for
yellow fever as occurring in Madeira in 1738. I do wish that we could get
hold of Abreu's book and also that of Busto y Blanco!

Sorry that this is also written in a hurry, as we have only one
collection of mail on Labor Day. Love to the Susans. Salvus sit!
